title: 107_s853
content: The "Targeted Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2001" includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically addressing the Dual-Earner Credit under section 25B. The "Targeted Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2001" includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifically addressing the Dual-Earner Credit under section 25B. This section allows a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year on a joint return, based on a specified amount determined for the taxpayer. The "Targeted Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2001" addresses the Dual-Earner Credit under section 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It provides a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year on a joint return, based on a specified amount determined for the taxpayer for different taxable years. The determination of the amount is calculated as the excess of the joint tentative tax over the combined tentative tax for the taxpayer. The joint tentative tax of a taxpayer for any taxable year is determined based on the table in section 1(a) on the joint tentative taxable income, which is the excess of earned income and taxable income received as a pension or annuity from an employer-employee relationship. The taxpayer's deduction for a taxable year is calculated by subtracting the standard deduction or total itemized deductions from the total exemption amount. The combined tentative tax of a taxpayer for any taxable year is determined by adding the taxes on the individual tentative taxable income of each spouse, as per the table in section 1(c). The individual tentative taxable income of a spouse is the excess of earned income. The combined tentative tax of a taxpayer for any taxable year is determined by adding the taxes on the individual tentative taxable income of each spouse, which is the excess of earned income, pension, annuity, and social security benefits, minus the standard deduction or an election under section 63(e). The combined tentative tax of a taxpayer for any taxable year is determined by adding the taxes on the individual tentative taxable income of each spouse, which is the excess of earned income, pension, annuity, and social security benefits, minus the standard deduction or an election under section 63(e). One-half of the total itemized deductions and exemption amount for the spouse for the year are also considered. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Marriage penalty relief for earned income credit is addressed in Section 3. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Marriage penalty relief for earned income credit is addressed in Section 3. The phaseout percentage for joint returns with earned income exceeding the exemption amount is determined under subparagraph (A). The earned income credit percentage decreases for eligible individuals with qualifying children. Joint returns with earned income exceeding the exemption amount have a specific phaseout percentage. Inflation adjustment for earned income credit phaseout amounts is increased by $2,500. The amendment changes the year for a specific section and includes rounding adjustments. The effective date for these changes is after December 31, 2001.
